To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir: The Y. M. C. A.
piano is deteriorating so rapidly
under the constant moving to
which it. has been subjected recently that it will be necessary
entirely to stop allowing it to be
moved. This conclusion was
reached by the Y. M. C. A. under
the urgent advice of the Superintendent of Buildings, who has had
charge of moving the instrument.
Since it is not to be moved,
there is the question of where it
will be placed. For the present, it
will be in the auditorium of the
Civil Engineering Building and
those who desire to use it for
some function may obtain the key
at the Y. M. C. A. office.
We roalize that this will probably work considerable hardship
on those who have been accustomed to use the piano at the
Barn, but it is simply a matter of
keeping the piano in one place or
very soon having no piano in
any place. It has recently made
as many as six trips in one week,
traveling in all kinds of weather,
and though it has lasted unusually well, it has received very nearly all the moving it can stand. For
this reason it has been deemed
necessary to take the step that
we have taken in refusing to allow it to be moved in the future.
Of course, the best solution of
the problem would be to acquire
in some way another piano and
place one in the Barn, and the
other in the C. E. Hall. Unfortunately, the Y. M. C. A. is not at
present financially able to do this
alone, but we will be very glad to
receive any suggestions as to how
a piano might be acquired.
(Signed) Charles S. Sydnor,
Gen. Secy. Hopkins Y.M.C.A.
